question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective way to provide dietary enrichment for captive primates?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on dietary enrichment for captive primates reports that scattering food throughout the enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviours in rhesus macaques, reduced abnormal behaviours in chimpanzees, reduced aggression in lemurs, and increased foraging and overall activity in gorillas (1315). Hiding food in containers such as boxes, baskets or tubes—often with browse—raised activity levels and foraging behaviours in lemurs and gibbons (1316). Presenting food in puzzle feeders decreased food sharing and increased foraging, tool use, and time spent feeding, but also increased aggression in some cases and reduced inactivity (1318). Providing live vegetation in planters (e.g., planted rye grass with scattered sunflower seeds) led chimpanzees to spend more time foraging than when given browse and grass added with the normal diet (1327). Offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased time spent feeding and reduced inactivity in rhesus macaques (1335). Feeding individuals in social groups led to enrichment tasks being completed faster than when feeding alone, and the presence of groupmates increased consumption of unfamiliar foods during first encounters (1343). When provided with stinging nettles as browse, captive gorillas used processing skills seen in wild gorillas to forage (1332). No studies were found that directly tested providing nectar (including artificial nectar), providing access to food at all times (day and night), or feeding individuals in subgroups (1331; 1340; 1344).
summary_statements: Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased feeding and exploratory behaviours in rhesus macaques.
Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced abnormal behaviours in chimpanzees.
Scattering food throughout an enclosure reduced aggression in lemurs.
Scattering food throughout an enclosure increased foraging and overall activity in gorillas.
Hiding food in containers such as boxes, baskets or tubes raised activity levels and foraging behaviours in lemurs and gibbons.
Presenting food in puzzle feeders decreased food sharing.
Presenting food in puzzle feeders increased foraging, tool use, and time spent feeding.
Presenting food in puzzle feeders increased aggression in some cases.
Presenting food in puzzle feeders reduced inactivity.
Providing live vegetation in planters led chimpanzees to spend more time foraging than when given browse and grass added with their normal diet.
Offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased time spent feeding in rhesus macaques.
Offering fresh produce in place of pellet feed reduced inactivity in rhesus macaques.
Primates in social groups completed enrichment tasks faster than when feeding alone.
The presence of groupmates increased consumption of unfamiliar foods by primates during first encounters.
When provided with stinging nettles as browse, captive gorillas used processing skills seen in wild gorillas to forage.
No studies were found that directly tested providing nectar or artificial nectar.
No studies were found that directly tested providing access to food at all times, day and night.
No studies were found that directly tested feeding individuals in subgroups.

question_details.query: Which is a more effective breeding stimulus for amphibians: simulating rainfall with sound recordings or allowing them to hibernate?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence specific to the two actions named is limited: there is no captured evidence on the effects of simulating rainfall using sound recordings of rain/thunderstorms on amphibian breeding [1867], and no captured evidence on the effects of allowing temperate amphibians to hibernate [1868]. Related interventions simulating seasonal changes report some breeding responses: varying artificial rainfall to mimic wet/dry seasons stimulated breeding and egg deposition in two replicated, before-and-after studies in Germany and Austria, though in Germany no toadlets survived past 142 days [1872]. Varying enclosure temperature to simulate seasonal changes saw one of six females breed after a temperature drop and pond filling in Italy, and a before-and-after study in Australia reported increased breeding success when a pre-breeding cooling period was provided alongside several other measures including playing recorded mating calls [1864].
summary_statements: There is no captured evidence on the effects of simulating rainfall using sound recordings of rain or thunderstorms on amphibian breeding.
There is no captured evidence on the effects of allowing temperate amphibians to hibernate.
Varying artificial rainfall to mimic wet and dry seasons stimulated breeding and egg deposition in two replicated, before-and-after studies in Germany and Austria.
In a German study involving varied artificial rainfall, no toadlets survived past 142 days.
In Italy, varying enclosure temperature to simulate seasonal changes saw one of six females breed after a temperature drop and pond filling.
A before-and-after study in Australia reported increased breeding success when a pre-breeding cooling period was provided alongside several other measures, including playing recorded mating calls.
